On this page
  • Description of the method

Linear constrained truncated conjugate gradient¶

In general (that is when some linear and/or nonlinear constraints are provided), to determine a trust-region tangential step, COBYQA must solve a problem of the form

(1)¶\[\begin{split}\begin{array}{ll} \min & \quad f(x) = \inner{x, g} + \frac{1}{2} \inner{x, H x}\\ \text{s.t.} & \quad Ax \le b,\\ & \quad Cx = d,\\ & \quad \norm{x} \le \Delta,\\ & \quad x \in \R^n, \end{array}\end{split}\]

where \(g \in \R^n\) approximates the gradient of the nonlinear objective function at the origin, \(H \in \R^{n \times n}\) is a symmetric matrix that approximates the Hessian matrix of the nonlinear objective function at the origin, \(A \in \R^{m_1 \times n}\) and \(C \in \R^{m_2 \times n}\) are the Jacobian matrices of the linear inequality and equality constraints, \(b \in \R^{m_1}\) and \(d \in \R^{m_2}\) are the corresponding right-hand sides, and \(\Delta > 0\) is the current trust-region radius.

As mentioned in the section The unconstrained case of the description of the bvtcg method, it is usual to solve inexactly problem (1) using a truncated conjugate gradient method.
